comments.body:
even test binaries built with `rules_go` seem to have output here as if they've been `strip`ed, while the make build does not (even though we pass -ldflags etc.). 

I have some follow-up about how we handle that, but:
- I'm not sure we want to be always stripping e2e.test
- Even if we do, we need to discuss doing this in the modern go way with `-trimpath` toplevel flag instead of gc/ldflags, which do *not* have the same output or behavior (modern `-trimpath` replaces filepaths with import paths which would be a breaking change here and probably elsewhere, it's more portable and actually supported by go for reproducible builds, but ... that should be another PR/discussion)
+1 to using standard stuff like trimpath!
I guess `return` could be necessary like line 199 after `failf()` call to make the process stop.
nit: this doesn't seem like a great default

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +41,45 @@	baseURL                                           = flag.String("url", "https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/tree/master/", "location of the current source")
	confDoc                                           = flag.Bool("conformance", false, "write a conformance document")
	version                                           = flag.String("version", "v1.9", "version of this conformance document")
	totalConfTests, totalLegacyTests, missingComments int
)

comments.body: nit: would prefer it fail here instead of trying to proceed
Are we concerned that newer test files with older walk code will treat newer fields as descriptions?
Not really, we just add every other line in the comment block under the description after extracting the lines that has Testname and Version information.
For what you're doing this is likely sufficient. If you were trying to e.g. type check it, this would not be sufficient as it doesn't handle any e.g. wrong platform file exclusions.
I suggest adding a package comment here explaining what this does.
